title: <italic>MCU</italic> encodes the pore conducting mitochondrial calcium currents
abstract: Mitochondrial calcium (Ca<sup>2+</sup>) import is a well-described phenomenon regulating cell survival and ATP production. Of multiple pathways allowing such entry, the mitochondrial Ca<sup>2+</sup> uniporter is a highly Ca<sup>2+</sup>-selective channel complex encoded by several recently-discovered genes. However, the identity of the pore-forming subunit remains to be established, since knockdown of all the candidate uniporter genes inhibit Ca<sup>2+</sup> uptake in imaging assays, and reconstitution experiments have been equivocal. To definitively identify the channel, we use whole-mitoplast voltage-clamping, the technique that originally established the uniporter as a Ca<sup>2+</sup> channel. We show that RNAi-mediated knockdown of the <italic>mitochondrial calcium uniporter</italic> (<italic>MCU</italic>) gene reduces mitochondrial Ca<sup>2+</sup> current (<italic>I</italic><sub>undefined</sub>), whereas overexpression increases it. Additionally, a classic feature of <italic>I</italic><sub>undefined</sub>, its sensitivity to ruthenium red inhibition, can be abolished by a point mutation in the putative pore domain without altering current magnitude. These analyses establish that <italic>MCU</italic> encodes the pore-forming subunit of the uniporter channel.
